content: Several times in the past, I have looked for old service friends, as have so many on this forum. I post this to this area of the forum, because my concern is about procedure, and the value (or lack thereof) of this web site. I am NOT posting about a particular person, though I have an example. That person's name is "Barnes", and when I posted in the "find a Buddy" part of the site, or when I post in the forum "Navy Missing persons", I am able to relate two entirely different sets of facts, and therein lies the rub. When I go to the non forum, dedicated "Find A Buddy" part of the site, I am asked information that really implies someone is looking in a local phone book, and has no idea about finding a military friend. When I searched for "Barnes" in the dedicated search part of the site, I was ONLY allowed to enter name and home state, the rest, rank and branch was essentially irrelevant, since it was nearly 20 years ago, and i don't have current info, or i would look in the phone book myself! So, like looking in a phone book, it returned just about all the Navy Barnes in S. Carolina. On the other hand, going to the forum, where finding someone is a matter of the pure luck that someone may know him, I was able to list the year I knew him (important), what ship he was on that year (a slam dunk), and what his job on the ship was. So if someone is using a military database, a "Barnes" on "USS Halyburton, FFG40", during desert storm, and afterward in 1992, where he was the radioman, should produce an IMMEDIATE hit. So why does the official search site not allow such information? With what I know, I should already be talking to the guy! I am in full recognition that once someone separates, he could be hard to find. But this system doesn't even let me ID him during his service, so i can start somewhere. So what gives? Where do I need to go to find all these guys dating from Vietnam up to the '90's. I suspect it's not here, and I don't mind paying, here or elsewhere, nor do I find the forum at fault in any other way. I think I will enjoy it here. For 12 years I served as a civilian, Governor Appointed, volunteer Commissioner and Chairman, and Executive Committee Member for USS Kidd, DD661, the fabulously restored WWII Historic Destroyer we have here in Baton Rouge. We were the number one place for destroyer reunions in the US at Historical Ships. But I guarantee that their membership officers knew something about finding people that I don't know, and that this site may not have. I only wish I had asked when I had the chance. But at the time, I was serving their needs, and I knew where "Barnes" was. So its my bad that I did not foresee the future better, and plan ahead. So I finish by asking if someone can give an old guy a helping hand. What the hell am I doing wrong? Thank you for your attention, and possible help, Arthur Colley, Captain USA, Vietnam period, Okinawa and Korea, CO, 30th Ord, GMGS. 1971. PS: Take my example. With that kind of specific data, it should be easy to close in on me, at least to my point of separation, which would include my home state, and many other clues to find me. But it seems not, or I could find Barnes (and some of the others that still live).

content: You're not doing anything wrong. It's just that the data you seek may not be available. This site does not own the official data on current and previous military members. DOD does and it's only available to our search engine in so much as DOD allows it. Since 9/11, a lot of that has been restricted for PERSEC reasons, and justifiably so. A search may reveal a similar name from within our own members data bank, but not necessarily from DOD. Consequently, even if you had the opportunity to tailor your search to specifics, it probably wouldn't help. Finding lost brothers, especially from years ago, is a problem for us all and the Buddy Finder here is just one more tool in our box. But, like all tools, it isn't, and never will be, all inclusive. If you have copies of old orders which include a lost brother's SSN, you can send a letter to the Social Security Administration asking them to pass on a message for you. If he/she is making SS payments, they'll have the current address and will usually forward a message on to them. The will NOT, however, reveal that address. VA will do the same thing, provided that the person has signed up for VA benefits. Of course, as with all things government, it may take a long while.

content: Here is what I did Art. I wrote to the Department of License's (drivers license) in the Capital of the state where I knew they lived. I explained that I was trying to find an old service buddy and asked for their last address. Most of the time they would send it to me without charge. Once in awhile they would charge me. Maximum charge was ten dollars (worth the cost just to find a friend) I found several old friends from Nam that way. Good luck and come back on here and let us know if you accomplished your mission.

content: ZR do you have a unit site you can go to ? Many of us Wolfhounds who may not have served together found a buddy who was known by another hound on a unit site and that led to a hit. Post your name and time period on any sites involving your unit and see where it goes. It may even be that someone may know someone who knows the person you’re looking for. I got a call from Mike, the NCO who came in country and took my squad after I was wounded. He remembered my name because he said he got tired of hearing Sgt Ballentine wouldn’t do it that way, we had a good laugh about that. I got a call from the LT who took the platoon after I was wounded. Both in turn had information about some of the guys I had been searching for. Unfortunately I was told I could quit looking for some, they were KIA after I was gone. If you don’t go to unit reunions speak to someone who does, use every avenue to your advantage. I received a call from the last buddy I’d been searching for about 3 years ago, his name is Brian. There were other guys I served with and didn’t remember but we related stories about some of the same experiences and then found we knew many of the same people which lead to another avenue. I know how frustrating a search can be and spent hundreds of dollars just calling people with similar names. Good Luck.
